title: Block data for each annotator

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
**Description**
- When the annotators labeled data in workspace, another annotators also labeled this data in the same workspace and task. The problem is that data fetched does not be allocated for each user. In the other word, the first annotator labels for document 1, and the another also labels for document 1, they do not whether teammate have done this document or not. In current solution, annotator coming later will overlaps in the results of that of the first one. This makes many users work on the same task leading to conflict the results. 

**Solution**
- Data is allocated for each annotator, and invisible for the others but workload of the project is visualized
- Reference: https://rasa.com/docs/rasa-enterprise/user-guide/annotate-nlu-examples/

title: Active learning loop function with listener does not print output/progress to jupyter notebook/colab

labels.name: status: stale
labels.description: Indicates that there is no activity on an issue or pull request

body:
**Describe the bug**
I'm running an active learning loop with argilla in a jupyter notebook (colab). I've tested both [this notebook](https://docs.argilla.io/en/latest/tutorials/notebooks/training-textclassification-smalltext-activelearning.html) and [this notebook](https://docs.argilla.io/en/latest/tutorials/notebooks/deploying-textclassification-colab-activelearning.html#). As the active learning loop takes several minutes or longer when running Transformers, it would be great if progress updates from the active learning loop / listener could be printed directly below the active learning loop cell. The problem is that no progress updates (or any print(...) outputs from the `active_learning_loop()` function) are printed below the cell.
I feel like the issue is that the cell `active_learning_loop.start()` does not run continuously, but it runs quickly once and then it is released and all the code from the listener/active learning loop function is run in the background on a different process (or something like that). The loop and listener works, but it does not print anything to the notebook interface anymore.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. run either [this notebook](https://docs.argilla.io/en/latest/tutorials/notebooks/training-textclassification-smalltext-activelearning.html) or [this notebook](https://docs.argilla.io/en/latest/tutorials/notebooks/deploying-textclassification-colab-activelearning.html#)
2. open argilla and annotate 20 data points
3. wait for active learning loop to run in the background
=> the active learning loop works and 20 new texts will be added to argilla after a few minutes at each iteration. but no progress/output is printed to the cell with `active_learning_loop.start()`

**Expected behavior**
Progress updates (e.g. from the HuggingFace trainer or print statements from the active_learning_loop() function) should be printed below the `active_learning_loop.start()` cell.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS [e.g. iOS]: I've tried with both google colab and on my local machine (MacOS)
 - Browser [e.g. chrome, safari]: Edge developer version
 - Argilla Version [e.g. 1.0.0]: 1.6 (but I also tried earlier versions like 1.1.1)
 - ElasticSearch Version [e.g. 7.10.2]: 7.10.2 I think
 - Docker Image (optional) [e.g. argilla:v1.0.0]: `docker run -d --name quickstart -p 6900:6900 argilla/argilla-quickstart:latest` run on 12.04.23

**Additional context**
As active learning loops with Transformers can take quite long, especially on larger datasets, progress updates in the google colab interface/below the cell is quite important I think, otherwise too many users will think that the loop is not working because it can take many minutes

title: Add status to datasets and new publish endpoint
body:
# Description

This PR adds the following changes:
* Add a new `status` column to `datasets` table (non nullable and with a index).
* Add a new `PUT /api/v1/dataset/{dataset_id}/publish` endpoint that if possible will change the status of the dataset to `ready` to be annotated.
  * Only admins can publish a dataset.
  * Only datasets in `draft` status can be published (and changed to `ready`).
  * Only datasets with one or more annotations can be published.
* Add new `create_annotation` policy function allowing only to create annotations for a dataset if the user is admin and the dataset is in `draft` status.

title: feat: Allow exclude vectors when loading records
body:
# NOTE

~~PR #2576 must be merged first to make this PR "mergeable"~~

# Description

Work implemented in https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pull/2577 and https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pull/2540 tries to introduce a mechanism for:

1. Loading data with field projections (selecting which record fields will be loaded)
2. Allow partial updates when uploading projected records

Some problems of this flow are raised during the work:

- There is a field mismatch between client and API records. The proposed field projection is referring to the Record API data model, and aligning it with client representation can be messy and give an unexpected behavior
- The update flag mechanism is a bit cumbersome because of the client data projection and the record class validation alignments. So, even for a single field update, you need to retrieve extra fields to keep aligned the validations.

The field projection in `rg.load` function can introduce confusion because both record models, client, and API, are not aligned. So, I prefer to remove this functionality. Instead of that, we can introduce some extra parameters to load for setup if users want to exclude `vectors` or `metrics` when loading data. This will help to mitigate problems founds in #2398 

This option, together with changes introduced in #2576, allows users to load partial record info and still update it without losing stored data.

For example, if users want to add some metadata to already stored records, they could try the following flow:

```python
ds = rg.load(name=dataset, exclude_vectors=True)

for record in ds:
   record.metadata = ...

rg.log(name=dataset, records=ds) # This will update records only by adding the metadata info
```

Closes [#2398](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/2398)

Refs: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pull/2577 and https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pull/2540

title: Fix GPU usage & other minor improvements in `ArgillaSpaCyTrainer`
body:
# Description

After extensively testing `ArgillaTrainer` as of the latest release for `spaCy`, I've found some things that had to be fixed/improved/refactored:

* Since `gpu_id` was not provided in `ArgillaTrainer`, then it was not provided to `ArgillaSpaCyTrainer` so the GPU could only be used when using `ArgillaSpaCyTrainer` directly
* `ArgillaSpaCyTrainer.train` was still using `path` as the param instead of `output_dir`
* Remove unnecessary `requires_version` function calls in `ArgillaSpaCyTrainer`, and add `requires_version("spacy-transformers")` just when required
* Improve `gpu_id` param docstrings in both `ArgillaTrainer` and `ArgillaSpaCyTrainer`

title: ValueError when using prepare_for_training() on multi-label annotated Argilla dataset with single annotations

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

body:
**Describe the bug**
I'm getting a `ValueError` when trying to use the `prepare_for_training()` method to prepare a multi-label annotated Argilla dataset for training. I'm only getting the error when a given record has just a single annotation. Everything works fine if all records have more than one assigned annotation label.

**To Reproduce**
```python
import datetime
import argilla as rg

# Create dataset with a multi-label record that only has one annotation
dataset_rg = rg.DatasetForTextClassification(
    [
        rg.TextClassificationRecord(text=None,
                                    inputs={'title': 'This is the title of an article'}, 
                                    prediction=None, 
                                    prediction_agent=None, 
                                    annotation=['LABEL_1'], 
                                    annotation_agent='team', 
                                    vectors=None, 
                                    multi_label=True, 
                                    explanation=None, 
                                    id='12345', 
                                    metadata={'split': 'train'}, 
                                    status='Validated', 
                                    event_timestamp=datetime.datetime(2023, 4, 4, 9, 57, 59, 910986), 
                                    search_keywords=None)
    ]
)

# Prepare the dataset for training
dataset_rg.prepare_for_training(framework="setfit")
```
Generates the following error:
```python
ValueError: Class label 1 greater than configured num_classes 1
```

**Expected behavior**
Expect the method to return a `Dataset` that is ready for training.
```python
Dataset({
    features: ['id', 'text', 'label', 'binarized_label'],
    num_rows: 1
})
```

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS [e.g. iOS]: GitHub Codespaces - Ubuntu Linux
 - Argilla Version [e.g. 1.0.0]: 1.6.0

**Additional context**
The method works properly when the given record is multi-label AND has more than one annotation label, for example:
```python
import datetime
import argilla as rg

# Create dataset with a multi-label record that only has one annotation
dataset_rg = rg.DatasetForTextClassification(
    [
        rg.TextClassificationRecord(text=None,
                                    inputs={'title': 'This is the title of an article'}, 
                                    prediction=None, 
                                    prediction_agent=None, 
                                    annotation=['LABEL_1', 'LABEL_2'], 
                                    annotation_agent='team', 
                                    vectors=None, 
                                    multi_label=True, 
                                    explanation=None, 
                                    id='12345', 
                                    metadata={'split': 'train'}, 
                                    status='Validated', 
                                    event_timestamp=datetime.datetime(2023, 4, 4, 9, 57, 59, 910986), 
                                    search_keywords=None)
    ]
)

# Prepare the dataset for training
dataset_rg.prepare_for_training(framework="setfit")
```
Returns:
```python
Dataset({
    features: ['id', 'text', 'label', 'binarized_label'],
    num_rows: 1
})
```

title: Add datasets annotations create endpoint
body:
# Description

This PR adds a new v1 endpoint to create annotations for a specific dataset.

Notes:
* It includes the `text` and `rating` annotation types.
* `text` annotation settings is empty right now, we can add possible settings in the future if required. At the same time if a users specifies some settings values for this type of annotation they are discarded.
* `rating` annotation settings allow a `options` attribute that can store a list of objects. Every object has the structure `{"value": int}` only allowing integer values.
* `rating` annotation settings allow a `options` attribute with a minimum of 2 items and a maximum of 100. If it doesn't has many sense we can change these values.
* I have tried to use Pydantic's [discriminated unions](https://docs.pydantic.dev/usage/types/#discriminated-unions-aka-tagged-unions) to select between different models based on the `type` attribute for the annotations but without any luck. Looks like it has a bug and JSON serialization is not allowed for subclases using this. I have solved this using a dynamic validator but please tell me if there is another better way to solve this.

title: Dataset index creation
body:
New elastic search engine component and `create_dataset_index` method.

Some notes:

- This component work using the official elasticsearch component, we should provide also opensearch compatibility as the current API endpoints. But we can tackle this in a separate PR.

- The engine is using the dataset id as part of the index name. The `rg` prefix is included to simplify index policies definition (you can define a snapshot policy by defining a wildcard. For Argilla indices this would not be possible only using the dataset id as index name)

title: Releases/1.6.0
body:
## [1.6.0](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/compare/v1.6.0...v1.5.1)

### Added

- `ARGILLA_HOME_PATH` new environment variable ([#2564]).
- `ARGILLA_DATABASE_URL` new environment variable ([#2564]).
- Basic support for user roles with `admin` and `annotator` ([#2564]).
- `id`, `first_name`, `last_name`, `role`, `inserted_at` and `updated_at` new user fields ([#2564]).
- `/api/users` new endpoint to list and create users ([#2564]).
- `/api/users/{user_id}` new endpoint to delete users ([#2564]).
- `/api/workspaces` new endpoint to list and create workspaces ([#2564]).
- `/api/workspaces/{workspace_id}/users` new endpoint to list workspace users ([#2564]).
- `/api/workspaces/{workspace_id}/users/{user_id}` new endpoint to create and delete workspace users ([#2564]).
- `argilla.tasks.users.migrate` new task to migrate users from old YAML file to database ([#2564]).
- `argilla.tasks.users.create` new task to create a user ([#2564]).
- `argilla.tasks.users.create_default` new task to create a user with default credentials ([#2564]).
- `argilla.tasks.database.migrate` new task to execute database migrations ([#2564]).
- `release.Dockerfile` and `quickstart.Dockerfile` now creates a default `argilladata` volume to persist data ([#2564]).
- Add user settings page. Closes [#2496](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/2496)

### Changed

- `ARGILLA_USERS_DB_FILE` environment variable now it's only used to migrate users from YAML file to database ([#2564]).
- `full_name` user field is now deprecated and `first_name` and `last_name` should be used instead ([#2564]).
- `password` user field now requires a minimum of `8` and a maximum of `100` characters in size ([#2564]).
- `quickstart.Dockerfile` image default users from `team` and `argilla` to `admin` and `annotator` including new passwords and API keys ([#2564]).
- Datasets to be managed only by users with `admin` role ([#2564]).
- The list of rules is now accessible while metrics are computed. Closes[#2117](https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/2117)

### Removed

- `email` user field ([#2564]).
- `disabled` user field ([#2564]).
- Support for private workspaces ([#2564]).
- `ARGILLA_LOCAL_AUTH_DEFAULT_APIKEY` and `ARGILLA_LOCAL_AUTH_DEFAULT_PASSWORD` environment variables. Use `python -m argilla.tasks.users.create_default` instead ([#2564]).

[#2564]: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/2564

title: Move dataset dump to `train`, ignored unnecessary imports, & remove `_required_fields` attribute
body:
# Description

As of recent updates and findings, some things could be improved in `argilla.training`.

Since the `ArgillaSpaCyTrainer` needs to dump the dataset to disk before actually training the model, it has been moved out of the `__init__` so that the dataset/s are dumped once the `train()` method is called. Additionally, a warning message has been included to let the user know that the process may take longer due to the dataset dump being a requirement from `spaCy` training.

Besides that, some other things have been spotted:
* As the `ArgillaSetFitTrainer` and `ArgillaTransformersTrainer` imports are on the top of the file, those are imported when using any framework in `ArgillaTrainer`. So on, since some of those require specific dependencies, we've moved those inside their respective if-statements, so that e.g. `ArgillaSpaCyTrainer` doesn't require `setfit` to be installed.
* As of dfa1ee444b42fbe1831f2f3ca111146322385048, the param `fields` has been removed in `rg.load`, so on, the `_require_fields` attribute set in `ArgillaTrainer` is no longer valid.

**Type of change**

- [X] Improvement (change adding some improvement to an existing functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

Since the unit tests are being developed in the target branch, those have not been created in this PR, but the following script has been tested successfully!

```python
import argilla as rg
from argilla.training import ArgillaTrainer

rg.init(api_url="https://alvarobartt-argilla-datasets.hf.space", api_key="team.apikey")

trainer = ArgillaTrainer(name="ner", framework="spacy", train_size=0.8)
trainer.update_config(max_epochs=2)
trainer.train(output_dir="ner")
records = trainer.predict("I live in Barcelona.", as_argilla_records=True)

rg.log(
    records=records,
    name="ner",
    tags={
        "task": "NER",
        "family": "token-classification",
        "dataset": "gutenberg-time",
    },
)
```

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
The [Metrics documentation](https://docs.argilla.io/en/latest/reference/python/python_metrics.html) is filled with codeblocks like:
```python
>>> from argilla.metrics.token_classification import f1
>>> summary = f1(name="example-dataset")
>>> summary.visualize() # will plot three bar charts with the results
>>> summary.data # returns the raw result data
```
However, in core Python, this will not trigger any visualization occurring - this only works in Jupyter Notebook if `summary.visualize()` is the last line of a cell. This is because  `summary.visualize()` does not visualize, it only returns a plotly fig. This is fine, but just not well documented.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
Perhaps we can use the following structure instead:
```python
>>> from argilla.metrics.token_classification import f1
>>> summary = f1(name="example-dataset")
>>> fig = summary.visualize() # will plot three bar charts with the results
>>> fig.plot()
>>> summary.data # returns the raw result data
```

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
We can just leave it be.

**Additional context**
N\A

---

- Tom Aarsen

title: enhancement: Add `stacklevel` to warning in metrics method

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

body:
Hello!

## Pull Request overview
* Add `stacklevel=2` to `warnings.warn` in all metrics their visualize methods to give users a better understanding of the source of the warning.

## Details
### Current situation
Any of the metrics from the [Metrics docs](https://docs.argilla.io/en/latest/reference/python/python_metrics.html) can be used for this, but I'll use F1 to show the current behaviour. Note that `plotly` must not be installed.
```python
import argilla as rg
from argilla.metrics.token_classification import f1

rg.init(api_url="https://argilla-span-marker.hf.space/", api_key="team.apikey")

summary = f1(name="span-marker-bert-base-fewnerd-fine-super")
summary.visualize() # will plot three bar charts with the results
```
Results in:
```
[sic]\models.py:32: UserWarning: Please, install plotly in order to use this feature
%>pip install plotly
  warnings.warn("Please, install plotly in order to use this feature\n" "%>pip install plotly")
```
The proper behaviour is for the bottom line to *not* point to the `warnings.warn`. This can be modified using the `stacklevel` argument, which is 1 by default. For this PR, I've incremented it to 2, making it point one position higher in the call stack.

## After this PR
Since these changes, the output for that same script is:
```
[sic]\argilla_metrics.py:7: UserWarning: Please, install plotly in order to use this feature:
 > pip install plotly
  summary.visualize() # will plot three bar charts with the results
```

---

**Type of change**

- [x] Improvement (change adding some improvement to an existing functionality)

**How Has This Been Tested**

title: Cannot run several log concurrently

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: status: stale
labels.description: Indicates that there is no activity on an issue or pull request

body:
**Describe the bug**
Since `rich` dependency is included, the `rg.log` cannot be called concurrently:




**To Reproduce**
```python
import argilla as rg

ds_01 = ...
rg.log(ds_01, name="my-dataset", background=True)


ds_02 = ...
rgl.log(ds_02, name="my-dataset02", background=True)
```

title: bulk log fails in case of single record is anomalous

labels.name: status: stale
labels.description: Indicates that there is no activity on an issue or pull request

body:
**Describe the bug**
In case of logging records in bulk, single invalid record leads to failure for entire batch.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
```
import argilla as rg
valid_record = rg.TokenClassificationRecord(
                            text="My valid record",
                            tokens="My valid record".split(),
                            prediction=[("first", 0, 2), ("second", 3, 8)],
                            prediction_agent="stanford_openie"
                        )

invalid_record = rg.TokenClassificationRecord(
        text="My valid record",
        tokens="My valid record".split(),
        prediction=[("first", 0, 2), ("second", 0, 8)],
        prediction_agent="stanford_openie"
    )

records = [valid_record, invalid_record]
x = rg.log(name="mock-ds1", records=records)
```
Leads to 500 response on client side

Server side error log leads to following:
```
INFO:     127.0.0.1:60252 - "POST /api/datasets/mock-ds1/TokenClassification%3Abulk HTTP/1.1" 500 Internal Server Error
ERROR:    Exception in ASGI application
...
    return await dependant.call(**values)
  File "/home/ankushchander/workplace/open_source/argilla/src/argilla/server/apis/v0/handlers/token_classification.py", line 117, in bulk_records
    records=records,
  File "/home/ankushchander/workplace/open_source/argilla/src/argilla/server/services/tasks/token_classification/service.py", line 67, in add_records
    record_type=ServiceTokenClassificationRecord,
  File "/home/ankushchander/workplace/open_source/argilla/src/argilla/server/services/storage/service.py", line 66, in store_records
    record.metrics = metrics.record_metrics(record)
  File "/home/ankushchander/workplace/open_source/argilla/src/argilla/server/services/tasks/token_classification/metrics.py", line 278, in record_metrics
    predicted_tags = cls._compute_iob_tags(span_utils, record.prediction) or []
  File "/home/ankushchander/workplace/open_source/argilla/src/argilla/server/services/tasks/token_classification/metrics.py", line 313, in _compute_iob_tags
    return span_utils.to_tags(spans)
  File "/home/ankushchander/workplace/open_source/argilla/src/argilla/utils/span_utils.py", line 156, in to_tags
    raise ValueError("IOB tags cannot handle overlapping spans!")
ValueError: IOB tags cannot handle overlapping spans!
```
**Expected behavior**
I can think of following possible solutions: 
1. failed records should be communicated back to user so that they can be fixed. It is similar to how elasticsearch returns failed records in index, update apis. [my favourite]
2. silently ignore records with error while indexing valid records
3. Index all records. Ignore prediction logging in case of invalid records 

**Screenshots**

title: Add new API v1 datasets list endpoint
body:
# Description

This PR adds the first v1 endpoint for list datasets.

Some changes that we need to discuss:
- I have added `DatasetPolicyV1` class into `policies.py`. We can think into alternatives to split the policies into different versions if required.
- I have not used `response_model_exclude_none=True` into the new endpoint. I think it's not a good idea to remove attributes becase they are empty and I have taken the chance of not using it with this new v1.
- I have changed how database sessions are managed with the factories. Now it's possible to work with relationships so for example now the workspace is automatically created when a dataset factory is used.

title: Allow to setup a sync with HF datasets

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: status: stale
labels.description: Indicates that there is no activity on an issue or pull request

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Currently, importing and exporting data from/to the Hugging Face (HF) datasets hub is a manual task that can become cumbersome and error-prone. Therefore, it would be beneficial to have an automated sync mechanism that can import/export datasets from/to the HF datasets hub.

**Describe the solution you'd like**
I propose creating a startup configuration that includes HF security credentials, a list of datasets to sync, and a minimal sync policy. For example:


````bash
export HF_TOKEN=....
export HF_DATASETS="argilla/**, org-name/other-ds"
export HF_POLICY_SYNC_FREQ="30min"

python -m argilla 
`````

This command would create two new workspaces in argilla: argilla and org-name, with data synced from the HF hub for the argilla/** organization and the dataset org-name/other-dataset.


**Describe alternatives you've considered**
N/A

**Additional context**
It would be useful to have this feature for the HF spaces as well, allowing datasets to be synced directly in running spaces.

title: Bug in `DatasetForTextClassification._prepare_for_training_with_transformers` when `multi_label=True`
body:
**Describe the bug**

When calling `.prepare_for_training()` with the default arguments on a `DatasetForTextClassification` dataset with `multi_label=True` records, the `_prepare_for_training_with_transformers` function fails. This is due to the recent addition of the `context` key when building the 🤗`Dataset`.

Then, IMO the following line should either be removed or made optional just in case the `context` key is available.

https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/blame/ba4ae63dc43ae1d36aa0efcf03896bcf5d9206ee/src/argilla/client/datasets.py#L764.

So on, the bug was introduced in 1.5.0, as in 1.4.0 it works fine and the CI seems to be passing.

**To Reproduce**

Run the following script to reproduce:

```python
import argilla as rg

rb_dataset = rg.DatasetForTextClassification([
    rg.TextClassificationRecord(
        text="This is a sample text",
        annotation="pos",
        multi_label=True,
    )
])
rb_dataset.prepare_for_training()
```

**Expected behavior**

The `context` key shouldn't be mandatory, so as to ensure consistency with the previous datasets. So on, the code above should work and the CI should pass.

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
 - OS [e.g. iOS]: macOS
 - Browser [e.g. chrome, safari]: N/A

 - ElasticSearch Version [e.g. 7.10.2]: N/A

title: fix: Using backend config to check version
body:
# Description

The backend version check request is not using the backend configuration setup from Argilla, so in some security environments, this check may fail. 

Instead of using a standard http request, on this PR we use a widely compatible `OpenSearch` client to request the version info.

Closes #2311

title: Add `argilla.training` module for spaCy integration

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

body:
Currently, we are working on support for `transformers` and already wrapped up support for `setfit`. Ideally, we want to include support for `spacy` too. By default, we would like to see support for `token_classificaiton`, but due to the `prepare_for_training(framework="spacy", nlp=nlp)` method within Argilla, it should be straightforward to add `text_classification` support too. You can just look at the setfit implementation, but the outcome of the PR should be.

```python
from argilla.training import ArgillaTrainer
​
trainer = ArgillaTrainer("dataset_name", "model_path_or_name" framework="spacy", train_size=0.8)
trainer.update_config(num_epochs=2, **kwargs)
trainer.train(path="test_model")
records = trainer.predict("This is a test", as_argilla_records=True)
```

Even though spaCy focuses on CLI-based training it should be accessible via the Python client too and can thus be nicely integrated here too.

```python
from spacy.cli.train import train as spacy_train
config_path = "spacy_textcat/config.cfg"
output_model_path = "output/spacy_textcat"
spacy_train(
    config_path,
    output_path=output_model_path,
    overrides={
        "paths.train": "train.spacy",
        "paths.dev": "valid.spacy",
    },
)
```

Including some hyperparameter optimization might also be an option.

_Originally posted by @davidberenstein1957 in https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/2504#issuecomment-1480981433_
